titles.*: eXtreme Programming in real life at Codeborne

en: We are practicing it daily and are both happy and proud of it. I will tell about our daily routines and practices that make it work for us. I will leave space for questions so that you can get answers about the aspects of XP that interest you the most.

titles.*: What is Svelte and why you should be using it?

en: Svelte is a relatively young UI framework that we use in many projects at Codeborne. Anton will tell you why we think it is better than the alternatives.

titles.*: Build and Deploy a Kubernetes-based environment

en: An overview of a CI/CD pipelines based on Kubernetes and Implemented using the tools Argo Workflow, ArgoCD and Kaniko.

titles.*: Enhancing ChatGPT with API management and OpenAI API

en: As the usage of AI grows, we need scalable, performant, and secure API integrations.
In this talk, we will explore the benefits of integrating an open-source Apache APISIX API management solution with the OpenAI API.

Flutter is an open-source mobile app development framework, that allows building high-quality native mobile apps using a single codebase. It’s easy to learn, developers love it and it can help speed up your development by a lot. All this is possible without developers even needing to know, how Flutter actually works. To make the most out of Flutter, it’s important to have a good understanding of how it works under the hood. We’ll discuss some key concepts and techniques that make Flutter unique and powerful.

titles.*: Joy and Usefulness of Feedback Loops

en: This talk explores the power of feedback loops in personal growth and professional impact. Drawing from personal experiences, we discuss the usefulness of discovering and strengthening feedback loops, with a particular focus on how software engineers can leverage these loops to continuously improve their skills and effectiveness.

titles.*: How to use AI - even if you don't have a team of Data Scientists

en: Have you ever wondered how could you bring more intelligence to your product or company even if you don’t have a whole team of data scientists? If you are an Engineer or a Product Manager (or anywhere in between), join this session and learn how you, and your existing team, can bring the power of Machine Learning to your next project. We will discuss how you can leverage existing tools and techniques that will help you utilize AI - even if you don't have a dedicated team of Data Scientists around.

This storytelling about issues you might see each half-year when you are trying to fairy reward your employees, so-called "performance review" process. I will propose my approach and share my experience with focus on software engineers.

titles.*: Head of Software Development @ Eesti Energia
50 shades of Software Development in Eesti Energia

en: We will take the journey how Eesti Energia reached current state of Software development, what has been the pitfalls and success factors both on technical and human side.

Artjom will share insights into scaling, enriching and efficiently delivering events to the frontend via GraphQL subscriptions, WebSockets, Redis pub-sub and Kafka to have an interactive web app experience.

titles.*: Eight Poor Design Choices in Eight Years at Playtech

en: At a certain point in a tech company’s lifespan, it becomes abundantly clear that not all undertakings are completely successful. This point is nigh for Playtech as well, where previously hidden deficiencies may now be illuminated in searing light. Here, cautionary tales, unexpected outcomes, shocking revelations – all will be explored during this journey through some of Playtech’s most infamous mishaps.

Not every beginning has a happy ending… or any ending. Regardless of the outcome, most undertakings leave us with experiences we lacked when we started. They say that failure is a better teacher than success, and we have abused this idiom these past eight years. We humbly present to you, then, a window into the future (and past): aim for the cloud[s]; misapply ORM - thrice; see only nails when the only tool available is a hammer; Strings are not only attached but entangled in everything; multiple not-invented-here syndromes. We have all been here at least once.

One of the definitive characteristics of the consummate professional is the honest ability to recognize faults, even when those faults are touted as best practices; to address the process(es) which led to the cultivation of such deficiencies, and to have the courage to bring these issues to the forefront, even in the face of conventional thinking.

titles.*: Encryption Key Management Service in Microservice Platform

en: In a SaaS product, the customers want to ensure that all of their sensitive data is securely stored and nobody else has access to it. Wrike has a feature just for that use case: Wrike Lock.

The idea behind the Wrike Lock is to have all sensitive customer data encrypted using our internal keys. Internal keys are stored in the database as strings encrypted by the key managed by the client. This way, we can not maliciously decrypt the customer's data unless the customer would willingly provide us access to decrypt internal keys.

As we're growing and moving towards a microservice platform, the current solution of having the key management system per service is not plausible anymore. A new centralized approach is desperately needed, where a single service manages the keys, settings, and access to the client's KMS.

There goes the idea of Wrike's Encryption as a Service. A microservice caching the keys, validating that we still have access to the client's KMS, and issuing the keys to the services which need to encrypt or decrypt the customer's sensitive data.

Kubernetes is known to be a myriad of things, and when used in the appropriate context it provides the builder with multiple layers of helpful tooling. In this K8S day, Burak will first provide an introduction to the domain of K8S, then dive into the details of its innate high-availability and security tooling. He will tell us about how he built such an application that spanned millions of active users.

We started experimenting with Kubernetes in 2016 in Telia. Certainly still belive this is the way to go and the first target for new application deployments. It has been a long journey, let’s see what we’ve come up with and where are we struggling in DevSecOps teams.

Modern large-scale applications are a complex beast. You’ll often see them spanning hundreds of microservices, multiple data storage solutions and a variety of user-facing clients. End-to-end testing is a great tool to ensure all of the pieces play well together in concert. Join us in this from-the-trenches talk for an overview how Veriff handles system-wide end-to-end testing, the challenges we faced while building it and lessons learned after making E2E part of our regular deploy pipeline.

titles.*: Listen. Speak. Coach. Repeat: the basics of candid conversations

en: Gleb spent the past decade training people to speak with clarity and meaning to others, from founders to engineers to scientists and designers. He learned the hard way that the role of a coach and a leader is to listen and ask questions. Fundamentally, these skills can be broken down into components, learned, and mastered. Mastery demands a lot of candid feedback—which is why the session will be interactive and practical.

titles.*: Orchestration of pipelines on large amounts of data: the good, the bad and the ugly

en: The use case is how we reduced one pipeline processing from 6h to 1.5h and improved reliability by using best practices for processing (e.g. iterative), using Spark and improving how we integrate processing and orchestration code for easier testing. And a quick overview how the process could be even better with DBT.

Flaky tests may cause plenty of headache to the engineers. Tests that passed just yesterday are now failing all of a sudden. No one chaned anything. It's just the wrong moon phase. It's just the matrix playing jokes on you. Novices just re-run the build, but real pros look into very gist of the problem. Each investigation unfolds a real crime scene. Sometimes it takes years.

I'll show some flaky tests from real projects and most importantly - how the truth could have been found there. Dedicated to automation and software engineers. To everyone who's into software testing and hard problems.

Tiit will look into evolution of testing as discipline and what might be there in future. Software testing has become integral part of development already long time ago but changes in approaches are becoming more frequent and involve growing need for technical skills and is moving towards production vs pre-release testing.

Good application logs make debugging issues much easier, but they come with limitations. The usual human-readable prose is hard to parse, search, and correlate. We’ll look at how structured logs and JSON output make your life easier, get metrics straight out of the logs, and see how Veriff's automation team is using it all in practice.

There is a wonder-drug, that makes you live longer, enhances your memory and creativity; makes you more attractive, slimmer and lowers food cravings. It also protects you from cancer and dementia, wards off colds, lowers your risk of strokes and heart disease. On top of that - this particular drug makes you more more happy, less depressed and less anxious. Want some?

Veriff was started in 2015, but the first BI analyst didn’t join until the end of 2018. Over the last year, we’ve taken huge strides in becoming more data-driven. Now we have a dedicated team of four analysts and data scientists working on empowering Veriff with data. Here’s how we did it, and some of the things we learned on the way.

titles.*: IaC evolution (how to avoid 💩 in the end)

en: It's 2019, and IaC is not a new term at all. But it's still not an easy thing. In this talk we will go through a couple of easy steps that can help in your DevOps journey 😉.

titles.*: Infrastructure as Code - we're doing it wrong

en: IaC has been around for a while now, but still creates a lot of debate. Is there a right and wrong approach to take? What can we learn from different tools out there and should you just use Terraform? Let's take a quick look into IaC history, drill into Terraform and figure out how developers can make ops life better.

titles.*: Machine learning from scratch in 4 months

en: Everybody knows what is a post office, but how we can improve the work in it and make the process easier with ML.
In this presentation, we will consider the real problem from different sides, show how we tackled it and what we achieved.

titles.*: Developers: To blame or not to blame?

en: While the cyber threat landscape keeps constantly evolving, security become more crucial for companies. We read daily about new data breaches tied to an application security vulnerability. What is behind all these vulnerabilities? Why do they keep happening? Margus Ernits will talk about building a security culture that is able to keep pace with the threat landscape. You will learn how to (not) build a security culture in your development team.

titles.*: Shit, I got promoted and I'm now a leader... So what now

en: This one is a crash course for those who just got promoted into leadership and are struggling finding their ways around the new challenges they’re now facing. Miguel will share his best insights on being a genuine leader that people love to work with.

place.addr: Telliskivi 60/2i-hoone B korpus, II korrus, 10412 Tallinn
place.name: Monese

titles.*: Exploring GraphQL-Braid: Leaving RESTish world and building a distributed GraphQL system

en: Do you have 100 microservices on your backend all exposing an API? And Android and iOS apps trying to communicate with them?

You would probably create a funnel-like API which forwards app calls, collects and returns the data. Then the app guys ask you to return one more field to the endpoint or create a new endpoint. A simple GET request (DB-wise). You plan, you build, you release. App engineers are waiting. Product guys are waiting. Users are waiting!
Then you wake up one day and see that you have an age-old endpoint which returns half of the database. You have to put an end to this mess! What options are there?

In this session we will share the result of our GraphQL and Atlassian Braid exploration journey. We are building a new distributed services architecture which will combine GraphQL backends into one schema. The result should be a fast, safe and easily maintainable cluster of microservices.

titles.*: Burnout syndrome – why should you take it serious

en: In this talk, I will share my experience with burnout syndrome – symptoms, how to avoid or cope with it and will use mega patented Chopstick method to explain why should you take it serious.

Being Reactive is the key to staying within the modern standards. We start with a simple MVC style application. First, we define a modern system. Then we introduce and solve the problems with the application. We will keep our REST API working the same way while utilizing Event Driven Architecture and many more!

en: TeamCity is a great tool for Continuous Integration with a lot of advanced features provided out-of-the-box. In this session, we will learn how TeamCity helps the software development in the daily routine; what was added to the product in the latest releases; what features are coming next.

titles.*: Observability - the good, the bad and the ugly

en: It covers general problem of creating monitoring and observability without killing your Ops motivation team with False Positives and unexplained alerts. Problems on this side, pitfalls, anti-patterns, and how to make it right.

How to manage a monitoring zoo. Spaghettification of dashboards. Why Uber needs 9 billion metrics and why this is antipattern. Metrics as a stream of data. We talk about new Flux language from InfluxDb. A bit of time series analysis and defining of pipelines in Flux for metrics data. Drunkyard walk on your metrics or why to measure a randomness.
What’s wrong with static methods (apart from them not being inline with OOP conventions)? Is dependency injection really that great? Is there life after Spring?

These question have been causing a lot of flame for a long time now. Butts hurt bad, but the community haven’t reached the consensus yet. I will share how my own understanding of these things changed over time and where did I end up eventually.

The talk about Ervin’s experiments with Google Assistant devices. Where it feels natural and where it comes short. Why as developer you should consider this platform for your products, and of course, some "hello world" demo.

titles.*: Changing mindset regarding Quality Assurance Engineers. Software testing is harder than development.

en: Two decades ago when modern technologies were emerging, the idea that software should be tested before getting released was meaning only that someone has to act as a future user of the software what led to the concept of Manual Testing.

However, this was taking too much time, especially at the time when number of functions included in software were increasing so rapidly. This is why companies discovered that some actions which were being repeated for a number of times could be automated what was the basis for Automation Testing.

Although, this is a much faster process than Manual Testing, this is not enough to satisfy the needs of the company, because the way it is done is usually based on simulating logical actions which can be done by the future user. This means that work of the QA team members is limited to creating simple auto tests and doing some manual testing where it takes less effort than creating an auto test.

At the same time, having this idea HR officers are hiring people who are unable to bring QA forward in order to achieve better quality of the product. Ideally, the person who is the one responsible for quality should be involved in the process of development and not just having to assess what has been already done as well as to be able not only to test the product, but to be able to understand why the mistake has occurred what is possible only in case if QA specialist has sufficient programming background.

The speaker will tell how to change the mindset regarding Quality Assurance Engineers based on his own experience in the field as well as is about to give some pieces of advice that will help both the ones responsible for hiring QA specialists to recruit the most competent people and the ones pursuing careers in the industry to know what is expected from them.

titles.*: Dividing up Metropolises - Modelling Rent prices across the globe

en: Moving to a new city with your two poodles and a pianist grandma- what is the best neighbourhood for renting a place? While moving with your grandma might not be really relatable for many - we all have some very specific requirements when selecting a place to live. How to solve the nested comparison problem apartments - neighbourhoods - cities that matches your specific requirements? In the devclub we’ll tell you about the data and the science that went into creating an off the shelf solution for finding optimal place that matches your budget.

titles.*: Software Architect with Data Science and Financial Background

en: Сoncurrency and Parallelism. Context switch pain. Functional approach. Java Reactive Revolution. Blocking vs NonBlocking execution. Functional Architecture.

What doesn't mean (and cost) to have a personal privacy? Why anyone would ever need that? What are consequences of stealing your digital persona? Is GDPR here for good or not? There are more and more questions raising and Kirils will try to answer all of them based on personal experience.

titles.*: Differences between software (engineering) and data engineering

en: A brief introduction to what it takes an experienced software engineer to enter the data engineering world.

titles.*: Achieving low latency communication between services and robots

en: How we brought a solution of handling robots online from several robots to thousands of robots? The future is here.

titles.*: Robot scheduling challenges compare to taxi orchestration

en: Is delivery robot logistics easy as package courier milk-run or complicated as taxi orchestration? What we are facing now, how that is solved and what will wait for us ahead?

Consumer driven contract testing is a method of verifying that services (e.g. API consumer and an API provider) speak the same language. By providing examples, API consumers set expectations on providers on how they should behave on specific inputs.

A set of expectations forms a contract that's produced by consumers and is shared with providers. Contract obligations are verified by providers with tests that can be run in isolation, without having to set up integration testing environments.

That lets them evolve independently and get immediate feedback when they've broken any of their API consumers. Contract testing can be used anywhere where you have two services that need to communicate with each other but becomes especially useful in environments with many services (e.g. microservice architecture).

titles.*: Project clarity - Random rant from an old engineer
What is Tribes & Missions and how did Pipedrive get there?
How do you align the Product organization around a highly agile team setup such as Tribes & Missions?

en: This session takes you through the cool features of IntelliJ IDEA, uncovering not so commonly used features. We will review how to utilize the power of automated refactorings, shortcuts, fast navigation, and other features that the IDE provides for better productivity.

I will try to answer a quite uncertain and not an easy question - What does techical artist do? - based on game development at Gamesys. During this session we'll build a prototype and define its necessity.

titles.*: How to build a payment card product

en: For a long time payment cards used to be the domain of banks. In the last decade, the paradigm has shifted – we see more and more regular enterprises issuing their own cards, be it telcos, grocery store chains, various fintech startups etc. But what does it take to build a payment card from scratch? How do cards work? What is the anatomy of card transactions? This is a talk focusing on technical and product aspects of the card issuance, based on true story.

This talk is an introduction about technical aspects of how payment cards function, what technical protocols are involved and what are implementation complexities in a typical payments project. You will learn about concepts like 3DSecure, Authorisation and Clearing, Tokenization and know about novelties in the payment world, which will affect consumers in the nearest future.

titles.*: Kotlin DSL in under an hour

en: Learn how to create type-safe and statically typed DSLs in Kotlin. Uncover the language features that make DSL creation possible. We’ll take a look at a few practical examples and create a simple DSL ourselves. The session starts with an introduction to DSL related Kotlin language features.

Next, we create a simple DSL in a live coding session and then continue adding expressiveness and language features. We cover a number of examples, like JSON or XML builder’s, data binding, configuration & template engines. As a bonus, if time permits, we’ll take a look at Kotlin DSL example in TeamCity continuous integration server.
